data.title: Man in the Moon (1960)
data.meta_description: William is an unsuccessful guinea pig for a medical group interested in researching the common cold. He is soon fired and offered a job by the nearby National Atomic Research Center where they figure anyone who could fail at being a guinea pig is just what they need. They con William into thinking he will continue his guinea pig career by testing out some equipment for them before they send a group of astronauts to the moon.
data.text:
- Basil Dearden playing with the idea of isolation chambers impacting psychological states 3 years before The Mind Benders

- A complete lack of faith in established government institutions, politicians and political parties, etc. All in the service of light jokes of course with this being a comedy, but a much better look for Dearden compared to the horrendous experience that was The Blue Lamp - much more Victim and Sapphire than that.

- Charles Gray being essentially brainwashed to fall in love with Kenneth More, going as far as to explicitly mourn how repressed British society was, especially when it came to men expressing their affection for each other. A hint of Victim to come

- Kenneth More is…

One of any number of British comedies that indicate the obsession the world had with the space race at the start of the sixties (The Bulldog Breed, Heavens Above, The Mouse on the Moon, etc). Which is rather odd in that Britain never had anything remotely like a space project.

And Man in the Moon, like all of those others has a level of scientific accuracy which barely gets above zero per cent. Looking at these sorts of films now one wonders just how taken in by the phoney science viewers were at the time the film was released because for the modern viewer there is nothing about it which isn't cringeworthy.

The story itself focuses on a professional guinea…

I last saw this film when I was eleven, give or take a year or two each way. That’s over 50 years ago. I can’t remember if I liked it, but I remembered the sequence where Kenneth More was cheerfully undergoing his tests, while the other astronauts were suffering. They must have amused me. A comedy by the British director-producer team Basil Deardon and Michael Ralph. Deardon had started his career with comedies (George Formby, Will Hay), but during their long period at Ealing, Deardon and Relph didn’t get a chance at making any of the famous Ealing Comedies. But once they left Ealing they made a number of light comedies, as well as their dramas of Social Significance. I’m…
